title: Stress & Connection
description: Explore how stress affects your attachment and need for connection.

questions.text: How do I handle it when you're busy or distracted?
choices: I understand and give you space
I'm patient but miss you
I struggle with feeling secondary
I use the time for my own things

therapeutic.rationale: Response to partner's busyness reveals attachment activation. Understanding-and-space shows secure attachment; patient-but-missing shows balanced longing; feeling-secondary shows activated anxiety; own-things shows secure independence or avoidance. How you handle your partner's unavailability affects relationship quality.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different busyness responses can create misunderstanding. The struggling-secondary person may feel abandoned while their partner is simply busy with life. Communicate: 'When I'm busy, it's not about us.'
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared busyness responses suggest similar attachment orientations. You'll handle each other's busy times similarly.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you feel when your partner is busy or unavailable? What thoughts arise? Does your response help or create more distance?

questions.text: What's my attachment style when stressed?
choices: I seek more closeness and reassurance
I withdraw and need space
I become more independent
I stay pretty consistent

therapeutic.rationale: Stress activates attachment systems in predictable ways. Closeness-seekers have anxious attachment activation; withdrawers have avoidant activation; independence-boosters manage through self-reliance; consistent types have secure attachment. Knowing your partner's stress-attachment style helps you respond appropriately rather than personalizing their behavior.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different stress-attachment styles create relationship challenges. The stress-seeker may chase the stress-withdrawer, who retreats more. Recognize the pattern and don't personalize it.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared stress-attachment styles mean you'll respond to stress similarly. Two seekers will come together; two withdrawers will give space.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When you're stressed, do you move toward your partner or away? Does this help your relationship? What would be healthier?

questions.text: How do I prefer to maintain our connection when life gets busy?
choices: Quick check-ins throughout the day
Quality over quantity - focused time together
Physical presence even if we're doing separate things
Trust that we're connected even without constant contact

therapeutic.rationale: Connection maintenance during busy times reveals attachment needs. Check-inners need frequent contact; quality-focused need depth; presence-seekers need proximity; trust-based need secure confidence. Knowing how your partner maintains connection during busy periods helps you stay close despite demands.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different busy-time connection needs may cause disconnect. The check-inner may feel neglected by the trust-based partner; the quality-focused may feel the check-inner is superficial. Adapt to each other's needs.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared busy-time connection means you'll maintain closeness the same way during demanding periods.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When life is busy, how do you maintain your connection? Is this working? What would help you stay close during demanding times?

questions.text: What do I need to feel valued when you have other commitments?
choices: Knowing I'm still a priority
Being included in your plans when possible
Understanding why other things need attention
Nothing special - I trust our bond

therapeutic.rationale: Value-feeling needs during partner's commitments reflect attachment security. Priority-needing addresses abandonment fears; inclusion-wanting seeks belonging; understanding-seeking is cognitively flexible; trusting-bond shows secure attachment. Knowing what your partner needs to feel valued when you're busy helps you provide it.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different value-feeling needs during commitments require awareness. The priority-needer may feel dismissed by the trusting-bond partner's absence; the trusting-bond partner may not realize reassurance is needed.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared value-feeling needs mean you'll naturally provide what the other needs during busy times.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What do you need from your partner when they have other commitments? Do you communicate this? What would help you feel valued?

questions.text: How do I show I'm secure in our relationship?
choices: I give you space without anxiety
I communicate my needs clearly
I trust you without needing constant reassurance
I support your individual goals

therapeutic.rationale: How we show security reflects attachment style. Space-giving without anxiety demonstrates non-anxious attachment; clear communication demonstrates secure expression; trusting without reassurance demonstrates secure confidence; supporting goals demonstrates differentiation. Recognizing how your partner shows security helps you see their trust.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different security expressions may be misread. The space-giving partner may seem distant; the clear-communicator may seem demanding. Learn to recognize your partner's security signals.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared security expressions mean you'll recognize each other's trust. You show security the same way.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you show your partner you feel secure with them? Do they recognize these signals? What does feeling secure look like for you?
